div.p: Appius and Virginia. A tragedy. By John Webster.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: Is Appius sent for, that we may acquaint him
With the decree o'th' senate?

sp.speaker: Lictor
sp.l: He is, my lord, and will attend
Your lordships presently.

sp.speaker: Opp.
sp.l: Lictor, did you tell him that our business
Was from the senate?

sp.speaker: Lictor
sp.l: I did, my lord, and here he is at hand.
sp.stage: Enter Appius, his two cozens and m. Clodius.

sp.speaker: Appius
sp.l: My lords, your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: Appius, the senate greet you well,
And by us do signify unto you
That they have chosen you one of the decemviri.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: My lords, far be it from the thoughts
Of so poor a plebeian, as your unworthy servant
Appius, to soar so high: the dignity of so
Eminent a place would require a person
Of the best parts and blood in Rome.
My lords, he that must steer at th' head of an
Empire, ought to be the mirror of the times
For wisdom and for policy, and therefore
I would beseech the senate to elect one.
Worthy of the place, and not to think of
One so unfit as Appius.

sp.speaker: Min●..
sp.l: My lord, my lord ▪ you dally with your wits.
I have seen children oft eat sweet meats thus,
As fearful to devour them
You are wise and play the modest courtier right
To make so many 〈◊〉 of ●our delight

sp.speaker: Oppius.
sp.l: ●t you must ●ow, what we have once concluded
Cannot for any private man's affection
Be slighted: take your choice then with best judgement
Of these two proffers, either to accept
The place proposed you, or be banished Rome
Immediately: lictors make wa●: we expect
You speedy a resolution.

sp.speaker: 1. Cousin.
sp.l: Noble cousin,
You wrong yourself extremely to refuse
So eminent a place.

sp.speaker: 2. Cousin.
sp.l: It is a means
To raise your kindred. Who shall dare t'oppose
Himself against our family, when yonder
Shall sit your power, and frown?

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Or banished Rome!
I pray forbear a little. Marcus.

sp.speaker: Marcus. Cl.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: How dost thou like my cunning?

sp.speaker: Marcus. Cl.
sp.l: I protest
I was be-agued, fearing lest the senate
Should have accepted at your feigned refusal.
See how your kindred and your friends are mustered
To warm them at your sunshine. Were you now
In prison, or arraigned before the senate
For some suspect of treason, all these swallows
Would fly your stormy winter, not one sing:
Their music is the summer and the spring.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Thou observest shrewdly: well, ●e fit them ●ort.
I must be one of the decemviri,
Or banish't Rome. Banished laugh, my trusty Marcus,
I am enforced to my ambition.
I have heard of cunning footmen that have worn
Shoes made of lead some ten days fore a race
To give them nimble and more active feet:
So great men should, that aspire eminent place,
Load themselves with excuse and faint denial,
That they with more speed may perform the trial:
Mark his humility says one; how far
His dreams are from ambition ▪ says another:
he would not show his eloquence, lest that
Should draw him into office: and a third
Is meditating on some thrifty suit
To beg 'fore dinner. Had I as many hands
As had Briareus, I'd extend them all
To catch this office; 'twas my sleeps disturber,
My diets ill digestion, my melancholy
Past physics cure.

sp.speaker: Marcus.
sp.l: The senators return.

sp.speaker: Minu.
sp.l: My lord, your answer.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: To obey my lord, and to know how to rule
Do differ much: to obey by nature comes,
But to command by long experience.
Never were great men in so eminent place
Without their shadows. Envy will attend
On greatness till this general frame takes end.
Betwixt these extremes of state and banishment,
My mind hath held long conflict, and at last
I thus return my answer, noble friends,
We now must part, necessity of state
Compels it so.
I must inhabit, now a place unknown,
You see't compels me leave you. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: 1. Cousin.
sp.l: To banishment, my lord?

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: I am given up
To a long travel full of fear and danger,
To waste the day in sweat, and the cold night
In a most desolate contemplation,
Banished from all my kindred and my friends,
Yea banished from myself; for I accept
This honourable calling.

sp.speaker: Minu.
sp.l: Worthy Appius,
The gods conduct you hither: lictors, his robes.

sp.speaker: 2. Cousin.
sp.l: We are made for ever, noble kinsman,
'Twas but to fright us.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: But my loving kinsmen,
Mistake me not, for what I spoke was true,
Bear witness all the gods: I told you first,
I was to inhabit in a place unknown;
'Tis very certain, for this reverend seat
Receives me as a pupil, rather gives
Ornament to the person, than our person
The least of grace to it. I showed you next
I am to travel; 'tis a certain truth:
look by how much the labour of the mind
Exceeds the bodies, so far am I ●ound
With pain and industry, beyond the toil
Of those that sweat in war, beyond the toil
Of any artisan, pale cheeks, and sunk eyes,
A head with watching dizied, and a hair
Turned white in youth, all these at a dear rate.
We purchase speedily that tend a state.
I told you I must leave you, 'tis most true.
Henceforth the face of a barbarian
And yours shall be all one, henceforth I'll know you
But only by your virtue: brother or father
In dishonest suit shall be to me
As is the branded slave. Justice should have
No kindred, friends, nor foes, nor hate, nor love,
As free from passion as the gods above.
I was your friend and kinsman, now your judge,
And whilst I hold the scales, a downy feather
Shall as soon turn them as a mass of pearl
Or diamonds.

sp.speaker: Marcus.
sp.l: Excellent, excellent lapwing,
There's other stuff closed in that subtle breast.
He sings and beats his wings far from his nest.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: So gentlemen, I take it, here takes end
Your business; my acquaintance, fare you well.

sp.speaker: 1. Cousin.
sp.l: Here's a quick change, who did expect this cloud?
Thus men when they grow great do straight grow proud.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Now to our present business at the camp:
The army that doth winter 'fore Agidon,
Is much distressed we hear: Minutius,
You with the levies and the little corn
This present dearth will yield, are speedily
To hasten thither, so to appease the mind
Of the intemperate soldier.

sp.speaker: Minu:
sp.l: I am ready
The levies do attend me, our lieutenant
Send on our troops.

sp.speaker: Appius:
sp.l: Farewell Minutius.
The gods go with you, and be still at hand
To add a triumph to your bold command.

sp.speaker: Numitor.
sp.l: Noble Icilius. welcome, teach yourself
A bolder freedom here, for by our love
your suit to my fair niece doth parallel
Her kindred's wishes. There's not in all Rome
A man that is by honour more approved
Nor worthier, were you poor, to be beloved.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: You give me (Noble lord) that character
Which I could never yet read in myself:
But from your censure shall I take much care
To adorn it with the fairest ornaments
Of unambitious virtue: here I hold
My honourable pattern, one whose mind
Appears more like a ceremonious chapel
Full of sweet music, than a thronging presence.
I am confirmed, the court doth make some show
Fairer than else they would do; but her port
Being simple virtue, beautifies the court,

sp.speaker: Virginia.
sp.l: It is a flattery (My lord)
You breathe upon me, and it shows much like
The borrowed painting which some ladies use,
It is not to continue many days;
My wedding garments will outwear this praise.

sp.speaker: Numitor.
sp.l: Thus ladies still foretell the funeral
Of their lords kindness.
But my lord, what news?
sp.stage: Enter a servant, whispers Icilius in the ear.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: Virginius, my lord, your noble brother
Disguised in dust and sweat, is new arrived
Within the city: troops of artisans
Follow his panting horse, and with a strange
Confused noise, partly with joy to see him,
Partly with fear for what his haste portends,
They show as if a sudden mutiny
O'erspread the city.

sp.speaker: Numitor.
sp.l: Cousin take your chamber.
What business from the camp?

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: Sure sir it bears
The form of some great danger, for his horse
Bloody with spurring, shows as if he came
From forth a battle: never did you see
Amongst quails or cocks in fight a bloodier heel,
Then that your brother strikes with. In this form
Of o'erspent horseman, having as it seems,
With the distracting of his news, forgotten
House, friends, or change of raiment, he is gone
To th'senate house.

sp.speaker: Numitor.
sp.l: Now the gods bring us safety,
the face of this is cloudy, let us haste
To'th senate house, and there inquire how near
The body moves of this our threatened fear.

sp.speaker: Cl:
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Thor troublest me.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: My hand's as ready armed to work your peace
As my tongue bold to inquire your discontents.
Good my lord hear me.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: I am at much variance
Within myself, there's discord in my blood,
My powers are all in combat, I have nothing
Left but sedition in me.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: Trust my bosom
To be the closet of your private griefs.
Believe me, I am uncranny.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: May I trust thee?

sp.speaker: M. Clodius.
sp.l: As the firm centre to endure the burden
Of your light soot, as you would trust the poles
To bear on them this airy canopy,
And not to fear their shrinking. I am strong,
Fixed and unshaking.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Art thou? Then thine ever: I love.

sp.speaker: M. Clodius.
sp.l: Ha ha he.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Can this my ponderous secrecy
Be in thine ear so light? seems my disturbance
Worthy such scorn that thou deridest my griefs?
Believe me, Clodius, I am not a twig
That every gust can shake, but 'tis a tempest
That must be able to use violence
On my grown branches. Wherefore laughest thou then?

sp.speaker: M. Clodius.
sp.l: Not that you're moved, it makes me smile in scorn
That wise men cannot understand themselves,
Nor know their own proved greatness. Clodius laughs not
To think you love, but that you are so hopeless
Not to presume to enjoy whom you affect.
What's she in Rome your greatness cannot awe
Or your rich purse purchase? Promises and threats
Are statemens lictors to arrest such pleasures
As they would bring within their strict commands;
Why should my lord droop, or deject his eye?
Can you command Rome, and not countermand
A woman's weakness? Let your grace bestow
your purse and power on me. I'll prostrate you.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Ask both and lavish them to purchase ●ie
The rich fee-simple of Virginia's heart.

sp.speaker: M. Clodius.
sp.l: Virginia's!

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Hers.

sp.speaker: M. Clodius.
sp.l: I have already found
An easy path which you may safely tread,
Yet no man trace you.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Thou art my comforter.

sp.speaker: M. Clodius.
sp.l: Her father's busied in our foreign wars,
And there hath chief employment; all their pay
Must your discretion scantle: keep it back,
Restrain it in the common treasury.
Thus may a states-man 'gainst a soldier stand,
To keep his purse weak, whilst you arm his hand.
Her father thus kept low, gifts and rewards
Will tempt the maid the sooner; nay haply draw
The father in to plead in your behalf.
But should these fail, than siege her virgin tower
With too prevailing engines, fear and power.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Go then and prove a speeding advocate;
Arm thee with all our bounty, oratory,
Variety of promise.

sp.speaker: Valerius.
sp.l: L. Appius, the decemvirate entreat
Your voice in this day's senate. Old Virginius
Craves audience from the camp with earnest suit
For quick dispatch.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: We will attend the senate.

sp.speaker: Clodius,
sp.l: Be gone.
sp.stage: Enter Spurius, Opius, Valerius, Numitor, etc.

sp.speaker: Opius.
sp.l: We sent to you to assist us in this counsel
Touching the expeditions of our war.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Ours is a willing presence to the trouble
Of all state cares. Admit him from the camp.

sp.speaker: Opius.
sp.l: Speak the camps will.

sp.speaker: Virginius.
sp.l: The camp wants money, we have store of knocks,
And wounds God's plenty, but we have no pay,
This three months did we never house our heads,
But in yond great star-chamber; never bedded
But in the cold field-beds, our victual fails us,
Yet meet with no supply; we're fairly promised,
But soldiers cannot feed on promises;
All our provant, apparel's torn to rags,
and our munition fails us: will you send us
To fight for Rome like beggars? Noble gentlemen,
Are you the high state of decemviri,
That have those things in manage? Pity us,
For we have need on't. Let not your delays
Be cold to us, whose bloods have oft been heated
To gain you fame and riches. Prove not to us
(Being our friends) worse foes than we fight with:
Let's not be starved in kindness. Sleep you now
Upon the bench, when your deaf ears should listen
Unto the reckless clamours of the poor?
Then would I had my drums here, they might rattle,
And rouse you to attendance. Most grave fathers,
Show yourselves worthy stewards to our mother
Fair Rome, to whom we are no bastard sons,
Though we be soldiers. She hath in her store
Food to maintain life in the camp, as well
As surfeit for the city. Do not save
The foe a labour; send us some supply,
Lest ere they kill us, we by famine die.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Shall I (My lords) give answer to this soldier?

sp.speaker: Opius.
sp.l: Be you the city's voice.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Virginius, we would have you thus possessed,
We sit not here to be prescribed and taught,
Nor to have any suitor give us limit,
Whose power admits no curb. Next know, Virginius,
The camp's our servant, and must be disposed,
Controlled and used by us, that have the strength
To knit it or dissolve it. When we please
Out of our princely grace and clemency
To look upon your wants, it may be then
We shall redress them: but till then, it fits not
That any petty fellow waged by us
Should have a tongue found here before a bench
Of such grave auditors. Further, —

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Pray give me leave,
Not here? pray Appius, is not this the judgement seat?
Where should a poor man's cause be heard but here?
To you the statists of long flourishing Rome,
To you I call, if you have charity,
If you be humane, and not quite given o'er
To furs and metal, if you be Romans,
If you have any soldiers blood at all
Flow in your veins, help with your able arms
to prop a sinking camp, an infinite
Of fair Rome's sons, cold, weak, hungry, and clotheless,
Would feed upon your surfeit. Will you save them,
Or shall they perish?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: What we will, we will,
Be that your answer: perhaps at further leisure
We'll help you, not your merit but our pleasure.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: I will not curse thee, Appius, but I wish
Thou wert i'th' camp amongst the mutineers
To tell my answers, not to trouble me.
Make you us dogs, yet not allow us bones?
O what are soldiers come too! Shall your camp.
The strength of all your peace, and the iron wall
That rings this pomp in from invasive steel;
Shall that decay? Then let the foreign fires
Climb o'er these buildings; let the sword and slaughter
Chase the gowned senate through the streets of Rome.
To double dye their robes in scarlet; let
The enemies stripped arm have his crimsoned brawns
Up to the elbows in your traitorous blood;
Let Janus' temple be devolved, your treasures
Ripped up to pay the common adversaries
With our due wages. Do you look for less?
The rottenness of this misgoverned state
Must grow to some disease, incurable
Save with a sack or slaughter.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: You're too bold.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Know you our extremities?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: We do.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: And will not help them?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Hereafter.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Hereafter? when so many gallant spirits
That yet may stand betwixt you and destruction,
Are sunk in death? Hereafter? when disorder
Hath swallowed all our forces?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: We'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: Opius.
sp.l: Peace, fellow peace, know the decemviri,
And their authority; we shall commit you else.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Do so, and I shall thank you; be relieved
And have a strong house o'er me, fear no alarms
Given in the night by any quick perdue.
Your guilty in the city feeds more dainty
then doth your general. 'tis a better office
To be an under keeper than a captain;
The gods of Rome amend it.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Break up the senate.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: And shall I have no answer?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: So farewell.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: What slave would be a soldier to be censured
By such as ne'er saw danger? To have out pay,
Our worths and merits balanced in the scale
Of base moth-eaten peace. I have had wounds
Would have made all this bench faint and look pale
But to behold them searched. They lay their heads
On their soft pillows, poor upon then bags,
Grow fat with laziness and resty ease.
And us that stand betwixt them and disaster
They will not spare a drachma. O my soldiers,
Before you want, I'll sell my small possessions
Even to my skin to help you, plate and jewels
All shall be yours. Men that are men indeed,
The earth shall find, the sun and air must feed.

sp.speaker: Numitor.
sp.l: Your daughter, noble brother, heating late
Of your arrival from the camp, most humbly
Prostrates her filial duty.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Daughter rise.
And brother I am only rich in her,
And in your love, linked with the honoured friendship
Of those fair Roman lords. For you Icilius,
I hear I must adopt you with the title
Of a new son; you are Virginia's chief,
And I am proud she hath built her fair election
Upon such store of virtues. May you grow,
Although a city's child, to know a soldier
And rate him to his merit.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Noble father,
(For henceforth I shall only use that name)
Our meeting was to urge you to the process
Of our fair contract.

sp.speaker: Virgin.
sp.l: Witness gentlemen,
Here I give up a father's interest,
But not a father's love, that I will ever
Wear next my heart, for it was born with her
●d grows still with my age.

sp.speaker: Numitor.
sp.l: Icilius,
Receive her: witness noble gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Valer.
sp.l: With all my heart. I would Icilius could do as much
For me; but Rome affords not such another Virginia.

sp.speaker: Virgin.
sp.l: I am my father's daughter, and by him
I must be swayed in all things.

sp.speaker: Num.
sp.l: Brother, this happy contract asks a feast,
As a thing due to such solemnities.
It shall be at my house, where we this night
Will sport away some hours.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: I must to horse.

sp.speaker: Numitor.
sp.l: What, ride tonight ?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Must see the camp tonight .
'Tis full of trouble and distracted fears,
And may grow mutinous. I am bent to ride.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tonight ?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: I am engaged: short farewells now must serve,
The universal business calls me hence,
That toucheth a whole people. Rome, I fear,
Thou wilt pay use for what thou dost forbear.

sp.stage: Enter clown whispering Virginia, after her m. Clodius with presents.

sp.speaker: Virginia
sp.l: Sirrah, go tell Calpharina, I am walking
To take the air: entreat her company.
Say I attend her coming.

sp.speaker: Corbulo
sp.p: Madam, I shall: but if you could walk abroad, and get an heir, it were better, for your father hath a fair revenue, and never a son to inherit.

sp.speaker: Virginia
sp.l: You are, sirrah —

sp.speaker: Corbulo
sp.p: Yes I am sirrah: but not the party that is born to do that; though I have no lordships, yet I have so much manners to give my betters place.

sp.speaker: Virginia
sp.l: Whom mean you by your betters?

sp.speaker: Corbulo
sp.p: I hope I have learned to know the three degrees of comparison: for though I be bonus, and you melior as well as mulier; yet my lord Icilius is optimus.

sp.speaker: Virginia
sp.l: I see there's nothing in such private done,
But you must inquire after.

sp.speaker: Corbulo
sp.p: And can you blame us (Madam) to long for the merry day, as you do for the merry night?

sp.speaker: Virginia.
sp.l: Will you be gone sir? (●nd.

sp.speaker: Corbula.
sp.l: O yes, to my lady Calpurnia's. I remember my oer -

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: My father's wondrous pensive, and withal
With a supprest rage left his house displeased,
And so in post is hurried to the camp:
It sads me much; to expel which melancholy,
I have sent for company.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: This opportunity was ●illy waited,
It is the best part of a politician
When he would compass ought to fame his industry
Wisely to wait the advantage of the hours,
His happy minutes are not always present.
Express your greatest art, Virginia hears you,

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O I conceive the occasion of this harmony.
Icilius sent it, I must thank his kindness.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Let not Virginia wait her contemplation
So high, to call this visit an intrusion;
For when she understands I took my message
From one that did compose it with affection,
I know she will not only extend pardon,
But grace it with her favour.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You mediate excuse for courtesies,
As if I were so barren of civility,
Not to esteem it worthy of my thanks;
Assure yourself I could be longer patient
To hear my ears so feasted.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Join all your voices till you make the air
Proud to usurp your notes, and to please her
With a sweet echo; serve Virginia's pleasure.
As you have been so full of gentleness
To hear with patience what was brought to serve you
So hearken with your usual clemency
To the relation of a lover's sufferings:
Your figure still does revel in his dreams,
He banquets on your memory, yet finds
Not thoughts enough to satisfy his wishes,
As if Virginia had composed his heart,
And fills it with her beauty.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I see he is a miser in his wishes,
And thinks he never has enough of that
Which only he possesses: but to give
His wishes satisfaction, let him know
His heart and mine do dwell so near together,
that hourly they converse, and guard each other.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Is fair Virginia confident she knows
Her favour dwells with the same man I plead for?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: — Unto Icilius.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Worthy fair one,
I would not wrong your worth so to employ
My language for a man so much beneath
The merit of your beauty: he I plead for
Has power to make your beauty populous,
Your frown shall awe the world, and in your smile
Great Rome shall build her happiness;
Honour and wealth shall not be styled companions,
But servants to your pleasure.
Then shall Icilius (But a refined citizen)
Boast your affection, when lord Appius loves you.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Bless his great lordship, I was much mistaken,
Let thy lord know, thou advocate of lust,
All the intentions of that youth are honourable,
Whilst his are filled with sensuality.
And for a final resolution know,
Our hearts in love like twins alike shall grow.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Had I a wife, or daughter that could please him
I would devote her to him, but I must
Shadow this scorn, and soothe him still in lust.
What news yet of Virginius return?
Not any.
O the misery of soldiers!
They doubly starve us with fair promises.
We spread the earth like hail, or new reapt corn
In this fierce famine; and yet patiently
Make our obedience the confined ●ile
That starves us:
Soldiers, let us draw our swords
While we have strength to use them.
'Tis a motion
Which nature and necessity commands.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: You're of Virginius' regiment.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We are.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: Why do you swarm in troops thus? to your quarter.
Is our command grown idle? to your trench.
Come I'll divide you, this your conference
Is not without suspect of mutiny.
Soldiers, shall I relate the grievances.
of the whole regiment.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Boldly.
Then thus my lord.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: Come, I will not hear thee,
Sir you shall:
Sound all the drums and trumpets in the camp,
To drown my utterance, yet above them all
I'll rear our just complaint. Stir not my lord,
I vow you are not safe if you but move
A sinew till you hear us.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: Well sir, command us: you are the general.
No my lord, not I,
I am almost starved; I wake in the wet trench,
Loaded with more cold iron than a jail
Would give a murderer, while the general
Sleeps in a field bed, and to mock our hunger
Feeds us with scent of the most curious fare
That makes his tables crack, our pay detained
By those that are our leaders: and at once
We in this sad, and unprepared plight,
With the enemy, and famine daily sight.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: Do you threaten us?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Sir you shall hear him out.
You send us whips, and iron manacles,
And shackles plenty, but the devil a coin.
Would you would teach us that cannibal trick, my lord,
Which some rich men 'Ith' city oft do use:
Shall's one devour another?

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: Will you hear me?
O Rome thou'rt grown a most unnatural mother,
To those have held thee by the golden locks
From sinking into ruin; Romulus
Was fed by a she wolf, but now our wolves
Instead of feeding us devour our flesh,
Carouse our blood, yet are not drunk with it,
For three parts of 't is water.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: Your captain,
Noble Virginius is sent Rome,
For ease of all your grievances.
'Tis false.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ay, 'tis false.
He's stolen away from's, never to return,
And now his age will suffer him no more
Deal on the enemy, belike he'll turn
An usurer, and in the city air
cut poor men's throats at home sitting in's chair.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: You wrong one of the honourablest commanders.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Honourable commander?
Commander? I my lord, there goes the thrist
In victories, the general and commanders
Share all the honour as they share the spoil;
But in our overthrows, where lies the blame?
The common soldier's fault, ours is the shame.
What is the reason that being so far distant
From the affrighted enemy? we lie
'Ith' open field, subject to the sick humours
Of heaven and earth: unless you could bestow
Two summers of us? shall I tell you truth,
You account the expense of engines, and of swords,
Of horses and of armour dearer far,
Than soldiers lives.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Now by the gods you do.
Observe you not the ravens and the crows
Have left the city surfeit, and with us
They make full banquets. Come you birds of death,
And fill your greedy crops with humane flesh;
Then to the city fly, disgorge it there
Before the senate, and from thence arise
A plague to choke all Rome. Omnes. And all the suburbs ▪

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: Upon a soldier's word, bold gentlemen,
I expect every hour Virginius
To bring fresh comfort.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Whom? Virginius?
Now by the gods, if ever he return,
We'll drag him to the slaughter by his locks,
Turned white with riot and incontinence,
And leave a precedent to all the world,
How captains use their soldiers.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: See, he's returned ▪
Virginius, you are not safe, retire,
Your troops are mutinous, we are begirt
With enemies more daring, and more fierce,
Then is the common foe.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: My troops, my lord?

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: Your life is threatened by these desperate men,
Betake you to your horse.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: My noble lord,
I never yet professed to teach the art
Of dying. 〈◊〉, out troops grown mutinous?
he dares not look on me with half a face
That spread this wildfire. Where is our lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Sirrah, order our companies.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: What do you mean, my lord?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Take air a little, they have heated me.
Sirrah, is't you will mutiny?
Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Is your gall burst, you traitor?
The gods defend sir.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Or is your stomach sea sick, doth it rise?
I'll make a passage for it.
Noble captain, I'll die beneath your foot.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: You rough porcupine, ha.
Do you bristle, do you shoot your quills you rogue?
They have no points to hurt you, noble captain.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Wast you (My nimble shaver) that would whet
Your sword 'gainst your commander's throat, you sirrah?
My lord I never dreamt on't.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Slaves and cowards,
What are you choleric now? by the gods
The way to purge it were to let you blood.
I am i'th' centre of you, and I'll make
The proudest of you teach the aspen leaf
To tremble, when I breathe.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: A strange conversion.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Advance your pikes. The word,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Advance your pikes.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: See noble lord these are no mutineers,
These are obedient soldiers, civil men:
You shall command these, if your lordship please,
To fill a ditch up with their slaughtered bodies,
That with more ease you may assault some town.
So now lay down your arms. Villains and traitors,
I here cashier you. Hence from me my poison,
Not worthy of our discipline: go beg,
Go beg, you mutinous rogues, brag of the service
You ne'er durst look on; it were charity
To hang you, for my mind gives, you're reserved
To rob poor market women.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: O Virginius.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: I do beseech you to confirm my sentence,
As you respect me. I will stand myself
For the whole regiment, and safer far
In mine own single valour, then begirt
with cowards and with traitors.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: O my lord, you are too severe.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Now by the gods, my lord,
You know no discipline, to pity them.
Precious devils? no sooner my back turned,
But presently to mutiny?

sp.speaker: Omnes:
sp.l: Dear captain.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Refuse me if such traitorous rogues
Would not confound an army. When do you march?
When do you march, gentlemen?
My lord, we'll starve first,
We'll hang first, by the gods, do any thing
Ere we'll forsake you.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: Good Virginius,
Limit your passion.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Sir, you may take my place,
Not my just anger from me: these are they
Have bred a dearth i'th' camp: I'll wish our foes
No greater plague than to have their company:
Show but among them all so many scars
As stick upon this flesh, I'll pardon them.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: How now, my lord, breathless?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: By your favour. I ha' said.
Mischiefs confound me if I could not wish
My youth renewed again, with all her follies,
Only t'ave breath enough to rail against
These — 'tis too short.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: See gentlemen, what strange distraction
Your falling off from duty hath begotten
In this most noble soldier: you may live
The meanest of you to command a troop,
And then in others you'll correct those faults,
Which in yourselves you cherished, every captain
Bears in his private government that form,
Which Kings should o'er their subjects, and to them
Should be the like obedient. We confess
You have been distressed: but can you justly challenge
Any commander that hath surfeited,
While that your food was limited? You cannot.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: My lord, I have shared with them an equal for ▪
Hunger, and cold, marched through watery fens, tune,
Born as great burdens as the pioneer,
When scarce the ground would bear me.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: Good my lord, give us leave to proceed;
The punishment your captain hath inflicted
is not sufficient; for it cannot bring
Any example to succeeding times
Of penance worth your faulting: happily
It may in you beget a certain shame;
But it will in others a strong hope
Of the like lenity. Yet gentlemen,
You have in one thing given me such a taste
Of your obedience; when the fire was raised
Of fierce sedition, and the cheek was swollen
To sound the fatal trumpet, than the sight
Of this your worthy captain did disperse
All those unfruitful humours, and even then
Convert you from fierce tigers to stayed men:
We therefore pardon you, and do restore
Your captain to you, you unto your captain.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: The gods requite you, noble general.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: My lord, my lord:

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Your pardon noble captain.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Well, you are the general, and the fault is quit,
A soldier's tears, an elder brother's wit
Have little fault in them, nor do they season
Things worth observing, for their want of reason.
Take up your arms and use them, do I pray,
Ere long you'll take your legs to run away.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: And what supply from Rome?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Good store of corn.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: What entertainment there?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Most honourable,
Especially by the lord Appius.
There is great hope that Appius will grow
The soldier's patron: with what vehemency
He urged our wants, and with what expedition
He hasted the supplies, it is almost
Incredible. There's promised to the soldier
Besides their corn a bounteous donative;
But 'tis not certain yet when't shall be paid.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: How for your own particular?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: My lord,
I was not entered fully two pikes length
Into the senate, but they all stood bare,
And each man offered me his seat: the business
For which I went dispatched, what gifts, what favours
Were done me, your good lordship shall not hear,
For you would wonder at them, only this,
'twould make a man fight up to'th' neck in blood,
To think how nobly he shall be received
When he returns to'th' city.

sp.speaker: Minut.
sp.l: 'Tis well,
Give order the provision be divided
And sent to every quarter.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Sir, it shall.
Thus men must flight their wrongs, or else conceal them,
When general safety wills us not reveal them.
sp.stage: Enter two petitioners at one door, at the other m. Clodius.

sp.speaker: 1. Petit.
sp.l: Pray is your lord at leisure?

sp.speaker: M. Clodius.
sp.l: What is your suit?

sp.speaker: 1. Pet.
sp.l: To accept this poor petition which makes known,
My many wrongs in which I crave his justice,
And upright sentence to support my cause,
Which else is trod down by oppression.

sp.speaker: M. Clodius.
sp.l: My lords hand is the prop of innocence,
And if your cause be worthy his supportance
It cannot fall.

sp.speaker: 1. Petitioner.
sp.l: The gods of Rome protect him.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: What, is your paper too petitionary?

sp.speaker: 2. Petit.
sp.l: It leans upon the justice of the judge,
Your noble lord, the very stay of Rome.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: And surer basis, for a poor man's cause,
She cannot yield. Your papers I'll deliver,
And when my lord ascends the judgement seat,
You shall find gracious comfort.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: Where's your lord?

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: Icilius? fair Virginia's late betrothed?

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: Your ears, I hope, you have not forfeited,
That you return no answer. Where's your lord?

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: At's study.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: I desire admittance to him.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: Please you attend, I'll know his lordship's pleasure.
Icilius? I pray heaven she have not blabbed.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: Attend? A petty lawyer tother day,
Glad of a fee, but called to eminent place,
Even to his betters, now the word's, attend.
This gowned office, what a breadth it bears?
How many tempests wait upon his frown?

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: All the petitioners withdraw. L. Appius
must have this place more private ▪ as a favour,
Reserved for you, Icilius. Here's my lord.
sp.stage: Enter Appius with lictors afore him.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Be gone, this place is only spared for us,
And you Icilius. Now your business.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: May I speak it freely?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: We have suffering ears,
A heart the softest down may penetrate.
Proceed.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: We are private, pray your courtesy.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: My duty.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Leave that to th' public eye
Of Rome, and of Rome's people. Clodius there.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Place me a second chair; that done,
Remove yourself. So now, your absence Clodius.
Icilius sit, this grace we make not common
Unto the noblest Roman, but to you
Our love affords it freely. Now your suit?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: It is, you would be kind unto the camp.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Wherein, Icilius, doth the camp touch thee?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Thus: old Virginius, now my father in law,
Kept from the public pay, consumes himself,
Sells his revenues, turns his plate to coin,
To wage his soldiers, and supply the camp,
Wasting that useful substance which indeed
Should rise to me, as my Virginia's dowry.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: We meet that opposition thus Icilius.
The camp's supplies doth not consist in us,
But those that keep the common treasury;
Speak or entreat we may, but not command.
But sir, I wonder, you so brave a youth,
Son to a thrifty Roman, should ally you,
And knit your strong arms to such falling branches;
Which rather in their ruin will bear down
Your strength, than you support their rottenness.
Be swayed by me, fly from that ruinous house.
Whose fall may crush you; and contract with mine,
Whose bases are of marble, deeply fixed
To ●uger all gusts and impending storms.
Cast off that beggar's daughter, poor Virginia,
Whose dowry and beauty, I'll see trebled both,
in one allied to me. Smile you Icilius?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: My lord, my lord, think you, I can imagine
Your close and sparing hand can be profuse
To give that man a palace, whom you late
Denied a cottage? Will you from your own coffers
Grant me a treble dowry, yet interpose me
A poor third from the common treasury?
You must move me by possibilities,
For I have brains; give first your hand and seal,
That old Virginius shall receive his pay
Both for himself and soldiers, and that done,
I shall perhaps be soon induced to think,
That you who with such willingness did that —

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Is my love misprised?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Not to Virginia.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Virginia?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Yes Virginia, lustful lord.
I did but trace your cunning all this while.
You would bestow me on some Appian trull,
And for that dross to cheat me of my gold;
For this the camp pines, and the city smarts.
All Rome fares worse for thy incontinence.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Mine boy?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Thine judge. This hand hath intercepted
Thy letters, and perused thy tempting guests,
These ears have heard thy amorous passions, wretch,
These eyes beheld thy treacherous name subscribed.
A judge, a devil.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Come I'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Sit still, or by the powerful gods of Rome
I'll nail thee to the chair. But suffer me,
I'll offend nothing but thine ears.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Our secretary.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Tempt not a lover's fury, if thou dost
Now by my vow, insculpt in heaven, I'll send thee. —

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: You see I am patient.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: But withal revengeless.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: So, say on.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Hope not of any grace, or the least favour,
I am so covetous of Virginia's love,
I cannot spare thee the least look, glance, touch.
Divide one bare imaginary thought
Into a thousand, thousand parts, and that
I'll not afford thee.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Thou shalt not.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Nay, I will not.
Hadst thou a judge's place above those judges
That judge all souls, having power to sentence me,
I would not bribe thee, no not with one hair
From her fair temples.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Thou shouldst not.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Nay, I would not.
Think not her beauty shall have leave to crown
Thy lustful hopes with the least spark of bliss,
Or have thine ears charmed with the ravishing sound
Even of her harshest phrase.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Nay, thou shalt not.
She's mine, my soul is crowned in her desire,
To her I'd travel through a land of fire.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Now have you done?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: I have spoke my thoughts.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Then will thy fury give me leave to speak?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: I pray say on.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Icilius, I must chide you, and withal
Tell you, your rashness hath made forfeiture
Even of your precious life, which we esteem
Too dear to call in question. I● I wished you
Of my alliance, graft into my blood,
Condemn you me for that? O see the rashness
And blind misprision of distempered youth!
As for the maid Virginia, we are far
Even in least thought from her; and for those letters,
Tokens and presents, we acknowledge none.
Alas, though great in place, we are not gods.
If any false impostor hath usurped
Our hand or greatness in his own behoof,
Can we help that? Icilius, there's our hand,
Your rashness we remit; let's have hereafter
Your love and best opinion. For your suit,
Repair to us at both our better leisures,
We'll breathe in it new life.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: I crave your pardon.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Granted ere craved, my good Icilius.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: — Morrow.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: It is no more indeed. Morrow Icilius.
If any of our servants wait, without,
Command them in.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Our secretary,
We have use for him. Icilius, send him hither.
Again good morrow.
Go to thy death, thy life is doomed and cast.
Appius be circumspect, and be not rash
In blood as thou'rt in lust: be murderous still,
But when thou strikest, with unseen weapons kill.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: My honourable lord.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Deride me, dog?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Who hath stirred up this tempest in your brow?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Not you? Fie, you?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: All you Panthean gods,
Confound me, if my soul be accessary
To your distractions.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: To send a ruffian higher,
Even to my closet, first, to brave my greatness,
Play with my beard, revile me, taunt me, hiss me;
Nay after all these deep disparagements,
Threat me with steel, and menace me unarmed,
To nail me to my seat, if I but moved:
All these are slight, slight toys.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Icilius do this?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Ruffian Icilius, he that in the front
Of a smooth citizen, bears the rugged soul
Of a most base bandetto.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: He shall die for't.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Be not too rash.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Were there no more men to support great Rome,
Even falling Rome should perish, ere he stand:
I'll after him, and kill him.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Stay, I charge thee.
Lend me a patient ear; to right our wrongs,
We must not menace with a public hand;
We stand in the world's eye, and shall be taxed
Of the least violence, where we revenge:
We should smile smoothest where our hate's most deep,
And when our spleen's broad waking, seem to sleep.
Let the young man play still upon the bit,
Till we have brought and trained him to our lure;
Great men should strike but once, and then strike sure.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Love you Virginia still?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Do I still live?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Then she's your own. Virginius is, you say,
Still in the camp.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Now in his absence will I claim Virginia
To be the daughter of a bond woman,
And slave to me; to prove which, I'll produce
Firm proofs, notes probable, sound witnesses;
Then having with your lictors summoned her,
I'll bring the cause before your judgement seat,
Where, upon my infallid evidence,
You may pronounce the sentence on my side,
And she become your strumpet not your bride.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Thou hast a copius brain, but how in this
Shall we dispose Icilius?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: If he spurn
Clap him up close, there's ways to charm his spleen.
By this no scandal can redound to you;
The cause is mine; you but the sentencer
Upon that evidence which I shall bring.
The business is, to have warrants by arrest.
To answer such things at the judgement bar
As can be laid against her; ere her friends
Can be assembled, ere herself can study
Her answer or scarce know her cause of summons
To descant on the matter, Appius may
Examine, try, and doom Virginia.
But all this must be sudden.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Thou art born
To mount me high above Icilius' scorn.
I'll leave it to thy manage.

sp.speaker: Corbulo.
sp.l: What was that you said, nurse?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Why, I did say thou must bestir thyself.

sp.speaker: Corbulo.
sp.p: I warrant you I can bestir my stumps as soon as another, if fit occasion be offered; but why do you come upon me in such haste? is it because (Nurse) I should come over you at leisure?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Come over me, thou knave? what dost thou mean by that?

sp.speaker: Corbulo.
sp.l: Only this, if you will come off, I will come on.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: My lord hath strangers tonight : you must make ready the parlour, a table and lights; nay when, I say?

sp.speaker: Corbulo.
sp.p: methinks you should rather wish for a bed then for a board, for darkness then for lights; yet I must confess you have been a light woman in your time: but now.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: But now? what now, you knave?

sp.speaker: Corbulo.
sp.l: But now I'll go fetch the table and some lights presently.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: Some lights to usher in these gentlemen,
Clear all the rooms without there. Sit, pray sit.
None interrupt our conference.
Ha, who's that?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: My most — child, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Numitor.
sp.l: Fair Virginia, you are welcome.
The rest forbear us till we call. Sweet cousin,
Our business, and the cause of our discourse
Admits you to this council. Take your place.
Icilius we are private, now proceed.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Then thus; lord Appius doth intend me wrong,
And under his smooth calmness cloaks a tempest,
That will ere long break out in violence
On me and on my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: My good cousin,
You are young, and youth breeds rashness. Can I think
Lord Appius will do wrong, who is all justice,
The most austere and upright censurer
That ever sat upon the awful bench?

sp.speaker: Valer.
sp.l: Icilius, you are near to me in blood,
And I esteem your safety as mine own.
If you will needs wage eminence and state,
Choose out a weaker opposite, not one
That in his arm bears all the strength of Rome.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: Besides Icilius,
Know you the danger what it is to scandal
One of his place and sway?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: I know it kinsmen, yet this popular greatness
Can be no bugbear to affright mine innocence.
No his smooth crest hath cast a palped film
Over Rome's eyes. He juggles, a plain juggler.
Lord Appius is no less.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: Nay, than cousin,
You are too harsh, and I must hear no more.
It ill becomes my place and gravity,
To lend a face to such reproachful terms
'Gainst one of his high presence.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Sit, pray sit.
To see me draw his picture 'fore your eyes,
To make this man seem monstrous, and this god
Rome so adores, a devil, a plain devil.
This lord, this judge, this Appius, that professeth
To all the world a vestal chastity,
Is an incontinent, loose lecher grown.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: Fie cozen.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Nay 'tis true. Daily and hourly
He tempts this blushing virgin with large promises,
With melting words and presents of high rate,
To be the stale to his unchaste desires.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Possible?
'Tis actual truth, I pray but ask your niece.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Most true, I am extremely tired and wearied
With messages and tokens of his love;
No answer, no repulse will satisfy
The tediousness of his importunate suit.
And whilst I could with modesty and honour,
Without the danger of reproach and shame,
I kept it secret from Icilius;
But when I saw their boldness found no limit,
And they from fair entreaty grew to threats,
I told him all.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: True: understanding which
To him I went.

sp.speaker: Valer.
sp.l: To Appius?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: To that giant,
The high colossus that bestrides us all;
I went to him.

sp.speaker: Horatio.
sp.l: How did you bear yourself?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Like Appius, at the first, dissemblingly,
But when I saw the coast clear, all withdrawn,
And none but we two in the lobby, than
I drew my poniard, took him by the throat,
And when he would have clamoured, threatened death,
Unless he would with patience hear me out.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: Did he, Icilius?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: I made him that he durst not squeak,
Not move an eye, not draw a breath too loud,
Nor stir a fingar.

sp.speaker: Horatio.
sp.l: What succeeded then?

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: Keep fast the door there: sweet couz not too loud.
What then succeeded?

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: Why, I told him all,
Gave him his due, called him lascivious judge,
(A thousand things which I have now forgotten)
Showed him his hand a witness 'gainst himself,
And every thing with such known circumstance,
That he might well excuse, but not deny.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: How parted you?

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: Why friends, in outward show.
But I perceived his heart: that hypocrite
Was born to gull Rome, and deceive us all.
He swore to me quite to abjure her love;
Yet ere myself could reach Virginia's chamber,
One was before me with regreets from him,
I know his hand. Th' intent of this our meeting
Was to entreat your counsel and advice:
The good old man her father is from home,
I think it good that she now in his absence
Should lodge in secret with some private friend,
Where Appius nor his lictors, those bloodhounds
Can hunt her out. You are her uncle sir,
I pray counsel the best.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: To oppose ourselves
Now in this heat against so great a man,
Might in my judgement to ourselves bring danger,
And to my niece no safety. If we fall
She cannot stand; let's then preserve ourselves
Until her father be discharged the camp.

sp.speaker: Valer.
sp.l: And good Icilius, for your private ends,
And the dear safety of your friends and kindred,
Against that statist, spare to use your spleen.

sp.speaker: Icil
sp.l: I will be swayed by you. My lords, 'tis late,
And time to break up conference. Noble uncle
I am your growing debtor.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: Lights without there.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: I will conduct Virginia to her lodging.
Good night to all at once.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: The gods of Rome protect you all, and then
We need not fear the envious rage of men.

sp.speaker: Clodius. and lictors
sp.l: Bestow yourselves in some close shops,
About the forum, till you have the sight
Of fair Virginia, for I understand
This present morning she'll come forth to buy
Some necessaries at the sempster's shops:
Howe'er accompanied be it your care
To seize her at our action. Good my friends,
Disperse yourselves, and keep a careful watch.
'Tis strange that ladies will not pay their debts.
'It were strange indeed, if that our Roman knights.
Would give them good example and pay theirs.
The calendar that we lictors go by, is all dog days.
Right, our common hunt is still to dog unthrifts.
And what's your book of common-prayer?

sp.p: Faith only for the increase of riotous young gentlemen i'th' country, and bankrupts i'th' city.

sp.l: I know no man more valiant than we are, for we
Back knights and gentlemen daily.

sp.p: Right, we have them by the back hourly: your French fly applied to the nape of the neck for the French rheum, is not so sore a drawer as a lictor.

Some say that if a little timbered fellow would justle a great loggerhead, let him be sure to lay him i'th' kennel; but when we shoulder a knight, or a knight's fellow, we make him more sure, for we kennel him i'th' counter.

sp.l: Come, let's about our business.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: You are grown wondrous amorous of late,
Why do you look back so often?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Madam, I go as a Frenchman rides, all upon one buttock.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: And what's the reason?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Your ladyship never saw a monkey in all your life time have a clog at's tail, but he's still looking back to see what the devil 'tis that follows him.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Very good, we are your clogs then.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Your crest is grown regardant; here's the beauty ▪
That makes your eyes forgetful of their way.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Beauty? O the gods! Madam I cannot endure her complexion .

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Why sir, what's my complexion? .

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Thy complexion is just between a Moor and a French woman.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: But she hath a matchless eye sir,

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: True, her eyes are not right matches, besides she is a widow.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: What then, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Of all waters I would not have my beef powdered with a widow's tears.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Why, I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O they are too fresh madam, assure yourself they will not last for the death of fourteen husbands above a day and a quarter; besides, if a man come a-wooing to a widow, and invite her to a banquet contrary to the old rule, she will sooner fill her eye then her belly. Besides that, if he look into her estate, first, look you, here are four fingers, first the charge of her husband's funeral, next debts, and legacies, and lastly the reversion; now take away debts and legacies, and what remains for her second husband?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: I would some of the tribe heard you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: There's a certain fish, that as the learned divulge, is called a shark. Now this fish can never feed while he swims upon's belly, marry when he lies upon his back, o he takes it at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Well sir, about your business, make provision
Of those things I directed.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Sweet lady, these eyes shall be the clarks of the kitchen for your belly; but I can assure you woodcocks will be hard to be spoke with, for there's a great feast towards.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: You are very pleasant.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: And fresh cod is taken down thick and threefold, women without great bellies go together by the ears for't, and such a number of sweet toothed ca●ers in the market, not a calf's head to be got for love or money; muttons mutton now.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Why, was it not soever ?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: No madam, the sinners i'th' suburbs had almost ta'en the ●me quite away from't, 'twas so cheap and common: but now 'tis at a sweet reckoning, the term time is the muttonmonger in the whole calendar.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Do your lawyers eat any salads with their mutton.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Yes, the younger revellers use capers to their mutton, so long till with their shuffling and cutting some of them be out at heels again. A bountiful mind and a full purse ever attend your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: O I thank you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: See, yon's the lady.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I will buy up for your ladyship all the young cuckoos in the market.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: What to do?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: O 'tis the most delicatest dish I'll assure you, and newest in fashion : not a great feast in all Rome without a cuckoo.

sp.speaker: Clodi.
sp.l: Virginia. Virg sir.

sp.speaker: Clodi.
sp.l: Mistress you do not know me,
Yet we must be acquainted: follow me.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: You do salute me strangely. Follow you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Do you hear sir, methinks you have followers enough. Many gentlemen that I know, would not have so many tall followers as you have for the price often hunting geldings, I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: Come, will you go?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Whither? by what command?

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: By warrant of these men, and privilege
I hold even on thy life. Come ye proud dame,
You are not what you seem.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Uncivil sir,
What makes you thus familiar and thus bold?
Unhand me villain.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: What mistress, to your lord?
He that can set the razor to your throat,
And punish you as freely as the gods,
No man to ask the cause? Thou art my slave,
And here I seize what's mine.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Ignoble villain,
I am as free as the best King or consul
Since Romulus. What dost thou mean? Unhand me.
Give notice to my uncle and Icilius,
What violence is offered me ▪ clod. Do, do.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Do you press women for soldiers, or do you beg women, instead of other commodities; to keep your hands in ●e? By this light if thou hast any ears on thy head, as it is a question, I'll make my lord pull you out by th' ears, though you take a castle.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: Come, will you go along?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Whither should she go sir? here's pulling and haling a poor gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: Hold you your prating reverence, the whip
Shall cease on you for your smooth cozenage.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Are not you servant to lord Appius.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: Howe'er I am your lord, and will approve it
'Fore all the senate.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Thou wilt prove thyself
The cursed pander for another's lust,
And this your plot shall burst about your ears
Like thunderbolts.

sp.speaker: Clodi.
sp.l: Hold you that confidence,
First I will seat you by 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 co● of l●,
And then I'll ●alke with you.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: How now, fair 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: How now, gentlemen?
What's the offence of fair Virginia,
You bend your weapons on us?

sp.speaker: Lictor.
sp.l: Sir stand back, we fear a rescue.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: There's no need of fear,
Where there's no cause of rescue: what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: O my Icilius! Your incredulity
Hath quite undone me, I am now no more
Virginius' daughter, so this villain urges;
But published for his bond woman.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: 'Tis true my lord,
And I will take my right by course of law.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: Villains set her free,
Or by the power of all our Roman gods,
I'll give that just revenge unto my rage
Which should be given to justice. Bondwoman?

sp.speaker: Clodi.
sp.l: Sir, we do not come to fight, we'll deal
By course of law. My lord we fear a rescue.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: A rescue? never fear't, here's none in presence
But civil men. My lord, I am glad to see you.
Noble Icilius, we shall ever love you.
Now gentlemen reach your petitions.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: My lord, my lord.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Worthy Icilius, if you have any business defer't
Until tomorrow, or the afternoon,
I shall be proud to pleasure you.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: The fox is earthed, my lord you cannot wind him yet.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Stools for my noble friends. — I pray you sit

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: May it please your lordship.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Why uncivil sir?
Have I not begged for bearance of my best
And dearest friends, and must you trouble me?

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: My lord, I must be heard, and will be heard,
Were all the gods in parliament, I'd burst
Their silence with my importunity,
But they should hear me.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: The fellow's mad;
We have no leisure now to hear you sir.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: Hast now no leisure to hear just complaints?
Resign thy place oh Appius, that some other
May do me justice then.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: We'll hear't tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: O my lord,
Deny me justice absolutely, rather
them feed me with delays.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: Good my lord hear him,
And wonder when you hear him, that a case
So full of vile imposture, should desire
To be unfolded.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: I my lord, 'tis true,
The imposture is on their parts.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Hold your prating,
Away with him to prison, clamorous fellow.
Suspect you our uprightness?

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: No my lord:
But I have mighty enemies, my lord,
Will overflow my cause. See, here I hold
My bondwoman that brags herself to be
Descended of a noble family.
My purse is too scant to wage law with them,
I am enforced be mine own advocate,
Not one will plead for me. Now if your lordship
Will do me justice so, if not then know
High hills are safe, when seas poor dales overflow .

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Sirrah, I think it fit to let you know,
Ere you proceed in this your subtle suit,
What penalty and danger you accrue,
If you be found to double. Here's a virgin
Famous by birth, by education noble,
And she forsooth, haply but to draw
Some piece of money from her worthy father,
Must needs be challenged for a bondwoman.
Sirrah take heed, and well bethink yourself,
I'll make you a precedent to all the world,
If I but find you tripping.

sp.speaker: Clodius.
sp.l: Do it freely.
And view on that condition these just proofs.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Is that the virgin's nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: He● milch nurse my lord, I had a sore hand with her for a year and a quarter, I have had somewhat to do with her since too, for the poor gentlewoman hath been so troubled with the green sickness.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: I pray thee nurse entreat Sertorius
To come and speak with me.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Here is strange circumstance, view it my lord,
If he should prove this, it would make Virginius
Think he were wronged.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: There is a devilish cunning
expressed in this black forgery.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Icilius and Virginia, pray come near,
Compound with this base fellow. You were better
Disburse some trifle then to undergo
The question of her freedom.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: O my lord!
She were not worth a handful of a bride,
If she did need a bribe.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Nay, take your course,
I only give you my opinion,
I ask no fee for't. Do you know this fellow?

sp.speaker: Virginia.
sp.l: Yes my lord, he's your servant.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: You're i'th' right:
But will you truly know his character?
He was at first a petty notary,
A fellow that being trusted with large sums
Of honest citizens, to be employed
I'th' trade of usury; this gentleman,
Couching his credit like a tilting staff
Most cunningly it broke, and at one course
He ran away with thirty thousand pound,
Returning to the city seven year after,
Having compounded with his creditors
For the third moiety, he buys an office
Belonging to our place, depends on us,
In which the oppression and vile injuries
He hath done poor suitors, they have cause to rue,
And I to pity: he hath sold his smiles
For silver, but his promises for gold,
His delays have undone men.
The plague that in some folded cloud remains,
The bright sun soon disperseth; but observe,
When black infection in some dunghill lies,
There's work for bells and graves, if it do rise.

sp.speaker: Numitor.
sp.l: He was an ill prop to your house, my lord.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: 'Tis true my lord, but we that have such servants,
Are like to cuckolds that have riotous wives,
We are the last that know it: this is it
Makes noblemen suspected to have done ill,
When the oppression lies in their proud followers.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: My lord, it was some soothing sycophant,
Some base detracting rascal that hath spread
This falsehood in your ears.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Peace impudence, did I not yesterday, no longer since
surprise thee in thy study counterfeiting.
Our hand?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: 'Tis true, my lord.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Being subscribed
Unto a letter filled with amorous stuff
Unto this lady?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I have asked your pardon,
And gave you reason why I was so bold
To use that forgery.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Did you receive it?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: I did my lord, and I can show your lordship
A packet of such letters.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Now by the gods,
I'll make you rue it. I beseech you sir,
Show them the reason moved you counterfeit
Our letter.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Sir, I had no other colour.
To come to speak with her.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: A goodly reason!
Did you until this hour acquaint the lady
With your intended suit?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: At several times,
And would have drawn her by some private course
To have compounded for her liberty.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Now by a virgin's honour and true birth,
'Tis false, my lord, I never had a dream
So terrible as is this monstrous devil.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Well sir, referring my particular wrong
To a particular censure, I would know
What is your suit?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: My lord, a speedy trial.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: You shall obtain't with all severity,
I will not give you longer time to dream
Upon new slights to cloak your forgery,
Observe you this chameleon, my lords.
I'll make him change his colour presently.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: My lord, although th' uprightness of our cause
Needs no delays, yet for the satisfaction
Of old Virginius, let him be present
When we shall crave a trial.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Sir it needs not:
Who stands for father of the innocent,
If not the judge? I'll save the poor old man
That needless travel.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: With your favour sir,
We must entreat some respite in a business
so needful of his presence.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: I do protest,
You wrong yourselves thus to importune it.
Well, let it be tomorrow, I'll not sleep
Till I have made this thicket a smooth plain,
And given you your true honour back again.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: My lord, the distance 'twixt the camp and us
Cannot be measured in so short a time.
Let us have four days' respite.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: You are unwise;
Rumor by that time will have fully spread
The scandal, which being ended in one hour
Will turn to air: tomorrow is the trial,
In the mean time, let all contented thoughts
Attend you.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: My lord, you deal unjustly
Thus to dismiss her; this is that they seek for,
Before tomorrow they'll convey her hence
Where my claim shall not seize her.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Cunning knave,
You would have bond for her appearance? say.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I think the motions honest.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Very good.
Icilius shall engage his honoured word
For her appearance.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: As you please, my lord,
But it were, fitting her old uncle there
Were jointly bound with him.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Well sir, your pleasure
Shall have satiety. You'll take our word
For her appearance; will you not sir, I pray?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Most willingly my lord.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Then sir you have it,
And i'th' mean time I'll take the honoured lady
Into my guardianship, and by my life,
I'll use her in all kindness as my wife.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Now by the gods you shall not.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Shall not, what?

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Not use her as your wife sir.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: O my lord, I spoke it from my heart.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: I very likely.
She is a virgin sir, and must not lie
Under a man's forth coming; do you mark?
Not under your forth coming, lecherous Appius.

sp.speaker: Appi.
sp.l: Mistake me not, my lord: our secretary,
Take bonds for the appearance of this lady.
And now to you sir, you that were my servant,
I here cashier you; never shalt thou shroud
Thy villainies under our noble roof,
Nor scape the whip, or the fell hangman's book
By warrant of our favour.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: So my lord,
I am more free to serve the gods, I hope,
Now I have lost your service.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Hark you sirrah,
Who shall give bonds for your appearance, ha?
To justify your claim?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: I have none, my lord.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Away, commit him prisoner to his chamber:
I'll keep you safe from starting.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Why my lord?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Away, I will not hear you.
A judge's heart here in the midst must stand,
And move not a hair's breadth to either hand.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: O were thy heart but of the self same piece
Thy tongue is, Appius; how blessed were Rome!

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Post to the camp Sertorius, thou hast heard
Th'effect of all, relate it to Virginius.
I pray thee use thy ablest horsemanship,
For it concerns us near.

sp.speaker: Serto.
sp.l: I go my lord.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Sure all this is damned cunning.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: O my lord,
Seamen in tempests shun the flattering shore,
To bear full sails upon't were danger more.
So men o'er born with greatness still hold dread,
False seeming friends that on their bosoms spread:
For this is a safe truth which never varies,
He that strikes all his sails seldom miscarries.

sp.speaker: Icil.
sp.l: Must we be slaves both to a tyrant's will,
And confounding ignorance at once?
Where are we, in a mist, or is this hell?
I have seen as great as the proud judge have fallen:
The bending willow yielding to each wind,
Shall keep his rooting firm, when the proud oak.
Braving the storm, presuming on his root,
Shall have his body rent from head to foot;
Let us expect the worst that may befall,
And with a noble confidence bear all.

sp.stage: Enter Appius, Clodius, and a servant.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Here, bear this packet to Minutius,
And privately deliver't, make as much speed
As if thy father were deceased i'th 'Camp,
And that thou wentest to take th'administration
Of what he left thee. Fly.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I go my lord.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: O my trusty Clodius.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: My dear lord,
Let me adore your divine policy.
You have poisoned them with sweet meats, you have my lord.
But what contain those letters?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Much importance.
Minutius is commanded by that packet
To hold Virginius prisoner in the camp
On some suspect of treason.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: But my lord, how will you answer this?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Tush, any fault
Or shadow of a crime will be sufficient
For his committing: thus when he is absent
We shall in a more calm and friendly sea
Sail to our purpose.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Mercury himself
Could not direct more safely.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: O my Clodius,
Observe this rule, one ill must cure another;
As aconisum a strong poison, brings
A present cure against all serpent's stings.
In high attempts, the soul hath infinite eyes,
And 'tis necessity makes men most wise.
Should I miscarry in this desperate plot,
This of my fate in after times be spoken,
I'll break that with my weight on which I am broken.
sp.stage: Enter two serving men at one door, at the other Corbulo the clown melancholy.

sp.speaker: 1 serving.
sp.p: Why how now Corbulo? thou wast not wont to be of this sad temper. What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.p: Time's change, and seasons alter, some men are born to the bench, and some to the halter. What do you think now that I am?

sp.speaker: 1. Serving.
sp.l: I think thee to be Virginia's man, and Corbulo.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.p: No, no such matter: guess again, tell me but what I am, or what manner of fellow you imagine me to be?

sp.speaker: 1. Serving.
sp.l: I take thee to be an honest good, fellow.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Wide of the ●ow hand still Corbulo. Is no such man.

sp.speaker: 2. Serving.
sp.l: What art thou then?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.p: Listen, and I'll describe myself to you: I am something better than a knave, and yet come short of being an honest man; and though I can sing a ●ble, yet am accounted b● as one of the base, being indeed, and as the ca● stands with me at this present, inferior to a rogue, and three degrees worse than a rascal.

sp.speaker: 1. Serving.
sp.l: How comes this to pass?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.p: Only by my services success. Take heed whom you serve. O you serving creatures; for this is all I have got by serving my lady Virginia.

sp.speaker: 2. Serving.
sp.l: Why, what of her?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.p: She is not the woman you take he to be; for though she have borrowed no money, yet she is entered into bonds; and though you may think her a woman not sufficient, yet 'tis very like her bond will be taken. The truth 〈◊〉 is challenged to be a bond woman; now if she be a bond woman and a slave, and I her servant and vassal, what did you take me to be? I am an ant, a coat, a worm, a woodcock amongst birds, a hodmondod amongst flies, amongst curs a trindle tale, and amongst fishes a poor ipèr; but amongst serving men worse, worse than the man's man to the under yeomen Fewterer.

sp.speaker: 1. Serving.
sp.p: But is it possible, thy lady is challenged to be a slave? What witness have they?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.p: Witness these fountains, these floodgates, these wellsprings: the poor gentlewoman was arrested in the open market; I offered, I offered to bail her; but (Though she was) I could not be taken. The grief hath gone so far my heart, that 〈◊〉 I be made free, I shall never be mine own man. The lord Appius hath committed her to ward, and it is thought she shall neither lie on the knight side, not in the troping ward, for if he may have his will of her, he means to put 〈◊〉 in the hole. His warrant hath been out for her, but how the case stands with him, or how matters will be taken up with her, ●s yet uncertain.

sp.speaker: 2. Serving.
sp.l: When shall the trial be?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.p: I take it to be as soon as the morning is brought a-bed of a new son and 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: 2. Serving.
sp.l: And when is that ▪

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 to 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 every morning you know brings forth a new ●n, be they 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 short lived, for every night she drowns them in the western sea. But 〈◊〉 ●hese 〈◊〉, as too high for your d●ll app● 〈◊〉. Shall 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 you at the trial tomorrow?

sp.speaker: 1. Serving.
sp.l: By 〈◊〉 help 〈◊〉 ●e there.

sp.speaker: 2. Serving.
sp.l: And I, if I li● ▪

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.p: And I, if I die for 〈◊〉: here's my hand I'll meet you. It is thought my old master will be there at the bar; for though all the timber of his house yet stand, yet my lord Numitorius hath sent one of his posts to the camp to bid him spur cut and come to the sentence. O we have a house at home as heavy as if it were covered with lead. But you will remember to be there.

sp.speaker: 1. Serving.
sp.l: And not to fail.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.p: If I chance to meet you there, and that the case go against us, I will give you a quart, not of wine, but of tears; for instead of a new role, I purpose to break my fast with sops of sorrow.

sp.stage: Enter Virginius like a slave, Numitorius, Icilius, Valerius, Horatio Virginia like a slave, Julia, calphurina, nurse.

sp.speaker: Virginius.
sp.l: Thanks to my noble friends, it now appears
That you have rather loved me then my fortune,
For that's near shipwrecked: chance you see still ranges,
And this short dance of life is full of changes.
Appius! how hollow that name sounds, how dreadful?
It is a question, whether the proud lecher
Will view us to our merit; for they say,
His memory to virtue and good men
Is still carousing Lethe. O the gods,
Not with more terror do the souls in hell
Appear before the seat of Rhadamant,
Than the poor client yonder.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: O Virginius.
Why do you wear this habit? it ill fits
Your noble person, or this reverend place.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: That's true, old man, but it well fits the case
That's now in question. If with form and show
They prove her slaved, all freedom I'll forgotten.

sp.speaker: Icilius.
sp.l: Noble Virginius,
Put out a bold and confident defence:
Search the imposture, like a cunning tryer,
False metals bear the touch, but brook not fire:
their brittleness betrays them; let your breath
Discover as much shame in them, as death
Did ever draw from offenders. Let your truth
Nobly supported, void of fear or art,
Welcome whatever comes with a great heart.

sp.speaker: Virginius.
sp.l: Now by the gods, I thank thee noble youth.
I never feared in a besieged town
Mines or great engines like you lawyer's gown.

sp.speaker: Virginia.
sp.l: O my dear lord and father, once you gave me
A noble freedom, do not see it lost
Without a forfeit; take the life you gave me
And sacrifice it rather to the gods
Then to a villain's lust. Happy the wretch
Who born in bondage lives and dies a slave,
And sees no lustful projects bent upon her,
And neither knows the life nor death of honour.

sp.speaker: Icil:
sp.l: We have neither justice, no nor violence,
Which should reform corruption sufficient
To cross their black premeditated doom.
Appius will seize her, all the fire in hell
Is leapt into his bosom.

sp.speaker: Virginius.
sp.l: O you gods,
Extinguish it with your compassionate tears,
Although you make a second deluge spread,
And swell more high than Tenerife's high head.
Have not the wars heapt snow sufficient
Upon this aged head, but they will still
Pile winter upon winter?
sp.stage: Enter Appius, Oppius, Clodius, six senators, lictors.

sp.speaker: Appius.
sp.l: Is he come? say.
Now by my life I'll quit the general.

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: Your reverence to the judge, good brother.

sp.speaker: Virginius.
sp.l: Yes sir, I have learned my compliment thus,
Blessed mean estates who stand in fear of many,
And great are cursed for that they fear not any.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: What is Virginius come?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: I am here my lord.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Where is your daughter?

sp.speaker: Numit.
sp.l: Here my reverend lord.
Your habit shows you strangely.

sp.speaker: Virginia.
sp.l: O 'tis fit,
It suits both time and cause. Pray pardon it,

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Where is your advocate?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: I have none my lord.
Truth needs no advocate, the unjust cause
Buys up the tongues that travel with applause
In these your thronged courts. I want not any,
And count him the most wretched that needs many.

sp.speaker: Orator.
sp.l: May it please your reverend lordships?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: What are you sir?

sp.speaker: Orator
sp.l: Of counsel with my client Marcus Clodius.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: My lord, I undertake a desperate combat
To cope with this most eloquent lawyer:
I have no skill i'th' weapon, good my lord;
I mean, I am not travelled in your laws.
My suit is therefore by your special goodness
They be not wrested against me.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: O Virginius, the gods defend they should.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Your humble servant shall ever pray for you.
Thus shall your glory be above your place,
Or those high titles which you hold in court,
For they die blessed that die in good report.
Now sir I stand you.

sp.speaker: Orator
sp.l: Then have at you sir.
May it please your lordships, here is such a case
So full of subtlety, and as it were,
So far benighted in an ignorant mist,
That though my reading be sufficient,
My practice more, I never was entangled
In the like pursenet. Here is one that claims
This woman for his daughter. Here's another
Affirms she is his bondslave. Now the question
(With favour of the bench) I shall make plain
In two words only without circumstance.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Fall to your proofs.

sp.speaker: Orator
sp.l: Where are our papers.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Orator
sp.l: Where sir? I vow you're the most tedious client.
Now we come to't my lord. Thus stands the case,
